trans-unit.source: Get started with Azure Table storage and Visual Studio connected services | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Get started with Azure Table storage and Visual Studio connected services | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: How to get started using Azure Table storage in an ASP.NET project in Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: How to get started using Azure Table storage in an ASP.NET project in Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: This article describes how get started using Azure Table storage in Visual Studio after you have created or referenced an Azure storage account in an ASP.NET project by using the Visual Studio Add Connected Services dialog.
trans-unit.target: This article describes how get started using Azure Table storage in Visual Studio after you have created or referenced an Azure storage account in an ASP.NET project by using the Visual Studio Add Connected Services dialog.

trans-unit.source: This article shows you how to perform common tasks in Azure tables, including creating and deleting a table, as well as working with table entities.
trans-unit.target: This article shows you how to perform common tasks in Azure tables, including creating and deleting a table, as well as working with table entities.

trans-unit.source: The samples are written in C\# code and use the <linkText>Azure Storage Client Library for .NET</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The samples are written in C\# code and use the <linkText>Azure Storage Client Library for .NET</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: For more general information about using Azure table storage, see <linkText>How to use Table storage from .NET</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more general information about using Azure table storage, see <linkText>How to use Table storage from .NET</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Azure Table storage enables you to store large amounts of structured data.
trans-unit.target: Azure Table storage enables you to store large amounts of structured data.

trans-unit.source: The service is a NoSQL datastore that accepts authenticated calls from inside and outside the Azure cloud.
trans-unit.target: The service is a NoSQL datastore that accepts authenticated calls from inside and outside the Azure cloud.

trans-unit.source: Azure tables are ideal for storing structured, non-relational data.
trans-unit.target: Azure tables are ideal for storing structured, non-relational data.

trans-unit.source: Make sure the namespace declarations at the top of the C# file include these using statements.
trans-unit.target: Make sure the namespace declarations at the top of the C# file include these using statements.

trans-unit.source: Get a CloudStorageAccount object that represents your storage account information.
trans-unit.target: Get a CloudStorageAccount object that represents your storage account information.

trans-unit.source: Use the following code to get the your storage connection string and storage account information from the Azure service configuration.
trans-unit.target: Use the following code to get the your storage connection string and storage account information from the Azure service configuration.

trans-unit.source: NOTE - Use all of the above code in front of the code in the following samples.
trans-unit.target: NOTE - Use all of the above code in front of the code in the following samples.

trans-unit.source: Get a CloudTableClient object to reference the table objects in your storage account.
trans-unit.target: Get a CloudTableClient object to reference the table objects in your storage account.

trans-unit.source: Get a CloudTable reference object to reference a specific table and entities.
trans-unit.target: Get a CloudTable reference object to reference a specific table and entities.

trans-unit.source: To create the Azure table, just add a call to CreateIfNotExistsAsync() to the previous code.
trans-unit.target: To create the Azure table, just add a call to CreateIfNotExistsAsync() to the previous code.

trans-unit.source: You can insert multiple entities into a table in a single write operation.
trans-unit.target: You can insert multiple entities into a table in a single write operation.

trans-unit.source: The following code example creates two entity objects ("Jeff Smith" and "Ben Smith"), adds them to a TableBatchOperation object using the Insert method, and then starts the operation by calling CloudTable.ExecuteBatchAsync.
trans-unit.target: The following code example creates two entity objects ("Jeff Smith" and "Ben Smith"), adds them to a TableBatchOperation object using the Insert method, and then starts the operation by calling CloudTable.ExecuteBatchAsync.

trans-unit.source: To query a table for all of the entities in a partition, use a TableQuery object.
trans-unit.target: To query a table for all of the entities in a partition, use a TableQuery object.

trans-unit.source: The following code example specifies a filter for entities where 'Smith' is the partition key.
trans-unit.target: The following code example specifies a filter for entities where 'Smith' is the partition key.

trans-unit.source: This example prints the fields of each entity in the query results to the console.
trans-unit.target: This example prints the fields of each entity in the query results to the console.

trans-unit.source: You can write a query to get a single, specific entity.
trans-unit.target: You can write a query to get a single, specific entity.

trans-unit.source: The following code uses a TableOperation object to specify a customer named 'Ben Smith'.
trans-unit.target: The following code uses a TableOperation object to specify a customer named 'Ben Smith'.

trans-unit.source: This method returns just one entity, rather than a collection, and the returned value in TableResult.Result is a CustomerEntity object.
trans-unit.target: This method returns just one entity, rather than a collection, and the returned value in TableResult.Result is a CustomerEntity object.

trans-unit.source: Specifying both partition and row keys in a query is the fastest way to retrieve a single entity from the table service.
trans-unit.target: Specifying both partition and row keys in a query is the fastest way to retrieve a single entity from the table service.

trans-unit.source: You can delete an entity after you find it.
trans-unit.target: You can delete an entity after you find it.

trans-unit.source: The following code looks for a customer entity named "Ben Smith" and if it finds it, it deletes it.
trans-unit.target: The following code looks for a customer entity named "Ben Smith" and if it finds it, it deletes it.
